description.narrative: Darfur Community and Peace Building Fund (DCPSF), phase 2 (2012-2015). A community driven peace and reconciliation initiative. UNDP administers the fund which aims to foster dialogue and funding of small scale peace building initiatives at community level. The support is a second tranche for phase 2, in line with the new Results Strategy for Sudan, 2014-2016.

Darfur Community and Peace and Stability Fund (DCPSF) fas 2 (2012-2015) är en multi-partner trust Fund som administreras av UNDP. Syftet med fonden är att stödja initiativ som bidrar till att bygga förtoende mellan samhällen i Darfur och därigenom bidra till en stabilisering av regionen för att bereda återhämntning och återuppbyggnad. Under oktober 2014 beslutade styrelsen att förlänga DCSPF från 2016 till 2017. Detta möjligör för en allokeringsrunda med nya projekt under 2015. Sida ämnar stödja fonden för allokeringsrundorna under 2014 samt under 2015 med respektive 21 000 000 SEK.
Eftersom det är en fond så finns ingen traditionell budget. Sida har beräknat att uppskattningsvis så stödjer båda utbetalningarna på 21 000 000 SEK c:a 5 projekt under fonden samt kostnader för fondens tekniska sekreteriat.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2017Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: In 2016, the DCPSF implemented 26 projects during the year. 14 partners began their projects during 2016, while 12 are ongoing from previous years. International and Sudanese NGO partners were able to reach some 12,800 people (directly) and 740,000 people (indirectly) with peacebuilding, livelihood, and natural resource management support.
The DCPSF Technical Secretariat conducted a Perception Survey in early March-April 2017. Some 90 percent of the community members surveyed said they have trust and confidence on the reconciliation mechanisms available in their communities. Further, 89 percent of people surveyed stated the presence of peacebuilding mechanisms and peacebuilding actors has contributed to the stability of their communities by decreasing communal conflicts.
The DCPSF has supported Community Based Reconciliation Mechanisms that have managed over 1,838 community disputes. The CBRMs resolved 90 percent of these cases successfully. As in previous years, most cases have had to do with crop destruction and access to shared resources.
DCPSF-supported Natural Resource Management Committees, Farm Protection Committees, and committees formed to demarcate livestock migratory routes and delineate pasture land, directly addressed the causes and triggers of conflict in communities. Indeed, 90 percent of the community members surveyed felt there is positive interaction over shared resources in their communities.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
